title: Suuns - Zeroes QC
description:
Saw this band live recently, loved it. Couldn't find it anywhere on Pirate Bay so I decided to share. I will be, from now on, seeding alternative/indie music that, unfortunately, isn't on PB.

Suuns - Zeroes QC

1. Armed For Peace - 3:37
2. Gaze - 3:56
3. Arena - 5:11
4. Pie IX - 3:16
5. Marauder - 1:49
6. Sweet Nothing - 7:03
7. Up Past The Nursery - 3:22
8. PVC - 3:39
9. Fear - 1:58
10. Organ Blues - 3:44

From: BBC

"Recognised as ones to watch in 2011 by quarters of the music press with ears pressed rather closer to the underground sounds emanating from the other side of the Atlantic, Montreal quartet Suuns are a beguiling group that take wonderfully immersive, transfixing, repetitive electro elements and fuse them to quasi-stoner rock grooves and shoegaze atmospheres. At times Zeroes QC, their debut long-player, simultaneously stirs thoughts of Cluster and Comets on Fire, of Suicide gate-crashing the first studio sessions of a reformed Slowdive. ItÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s enthralling ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ perhaps not because of any pronounced originality, granted, but certainly due to how every element sits so well in the overall mix.
Produced by Jace Lasek of The Besnard Lakes ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ heÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s also worked on records by the likes of Young Galaxy, Wolf Parade and Patrick Watson ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ these tracks wander relatively far and wide in tone and texture. Soon as the listener thinks that they have the group pegged, along comes a number to toss that conclusion into the wildest winds. Pie XI is an example of such a side-step from an established sound, a chirruping, unsettling swirl of creepy child-like vocals and low-end pulsations. This, straight after the propulsive beats and clean, Interpol-y guitars of Arena. A comparison to Autolux isnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t too wide of the mark when Suuns are following a linear trajectory, Liam OÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢NeillÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s drums exact and Ben ShemieÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s vocals clear ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ but when the tangents come, theyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢re as distracting as a streaker interrupting play during a vital penalty shoot-out. Whether thatÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s a plus or minus point is down to the individual.
As a result, thereÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s not quite an established cohesion from piece to piece ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ no flawless thread that binds these tracks together as a whole. But this can easily be forgiven, given that itÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s a debut (a better-realised packaging of the bandÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s obvious potential will surely follow), and that the stylistic detours are always taken with confidence. Suuns arenÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t mixing up their genre bag just because they feel that they should; theyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢re taking the listener out of their comfort zone because, to them, itÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s totally natural to do so. Fans of the above-cited comparisons, plus the squelchy dance-prog-rock of the likes of Trans Am and Parts & Labor, are advised to check out Zeroes QC just as soon as the January blues have dissipated. Or sooner, indeed, as this sort of immediate and effortlessly enjoyable fare is certain to lift any grey skies ennui"
